{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3328518,"name":"Brad Collins","username":"bradleyscollins","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bradleyscollins/{size}/218979_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-09T15:59:29.936Z","cooked":"

Trying out unit testing. I have what I can only imagine is the simplest unit test possible (and I am noâ€™ a man given to superlaâ€™ives ):

  1. I created a new C++ project based on the Timed Robot template.
  2. I copied the example C++ test directly from the FRC WPILib website.
  3. I created a new test file, src\test\cpp\SampleTest.cpp, and pasted in the example test code.
  4. I removed anything to do with a robot and created my simple test.

All it is doing is just comparing two integers:

#include <gtest/gtest.h>

class SampleTest : public testing::Test
{
protected:
}

TEST_F(SampleTest, IntegersOfTheSameValueAreEqual)
{
    int a = 7;
    int b = 7;
    
    EXPECT_EQ(a, b);
}

And yet every time, it fails to build with the following error:

SampleTest.cpp(10): error C2059: syntax error: 'static_assert'

The Plot Thickens

If I create a new project from the UnitTesting example and put the same braindead integer comparison test into IntakeTest.cpp, it works like a charm.

Are you sure the path is right? Not src/test/native/cpp? The error doesnâ€™t make a lot of sense as thereâ€™s not a static_assert on line 10 of what you show as the file. Can you put the entire project that exhibits this problem on github so we can try to reproduce it?

Thank you, @Peter_Johnson, for the kind reply.

Yessir, I can confirm that the path is correct:

src\test\cpp\SampleTest.cpp

As the UnitTesting example project puts its test here:

src\test\cpp\subsystems\IntakeTest.cpp

â€¦ I even tried moving my sample test to â€¦

src\test\cpp\subsystems\SampleTest.cpp

Alas, no avail.

Finally, I did push it to GitHub.

Again, thank you very much for you help.

Ok, GCC gave a much more useful error message.

src/test/cpp/SampleTest.cpp:9:2: error: expected â€˜;â€™ after class definition
    9 | }
      |  ^
      |  ;

Youâ€™re missing a semicolon at the end of the SampleTest class definition. I should have caught that when I looked at your code pasted above!

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2024-03-09T17:32:06.666Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":23,"readers_count":22,"score":4.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":458022,"topic_slug":"simple-c-unit-test-not-building-error-c2059-syntax-error-static-assert","display_username":"Peter Johnson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":64938,"username":"bradleyscollins","name":"Brad Collins","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bradleyscollins/{size}/218979_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":13575,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA"},"post_url":"/t/simple-c-unit-test-not-building-error-c2059-syntax-error-static-assert/458022/4","custom_user_title":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":true,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3328599,"name":"Brad Collins","username":"bradleyscollins","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bradleyscollins/{size}/218979_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-09T18:54:40.189Z","cooked":"

Holy cow! Rookie mistake! And here I thought my test was the braindead thing â€¦ when I am the braindead one!

Iâ€™ve been doing Java & C# too long. I keep forgetting that C++ wants a semicolon at the end of a class definition.

Thank you again, @Peter_Johnson, for the kind help. And seriously, my sincere apologies for filing the inaccurate report. Though I could have sworn otherwise, obviously I did do more than just remove robot-related stuff.

Finally, would this be the wrong place for some good-natured griping about how egregious the C++ errors tend to be? This is not the first time that a missing semicolon triggered an error that was completely unhelpful in diagnosing the root cause. Seems as if they usually point us to someplace in library code, which is almost certainly the last place it will ever be.

Itâ€™s as if Douglas Adams wrote the error message:

XboxController.cpp line 47 is almost but not entirely where the cause of the error is not.

Yeah, GCC and clang seem to have put more work into helpful error messages (GCC used to be pretty bad but has made a lot of improvements in the last few versions). I find MSVC errors are really unhelpful a lot of the time.
